He is not only a past student, but he is the I lovingly curse when sorely roll out of bed the day after one of his workouts. Justin Thacker's blood runs SLU BLUE. He not only did his nutrition undergraduate program at SLU but also is a graduate of SLU's dietetic internship and future Masters degree student. He is a Registered Dietitian and Certified Strenght an

item.title: The Part of My Job I Wasn't Warned About
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
When I first started working at Saint Louis University about 2 years ago, I understood my responsibilities included teaching, advising, performing research, taking part in committees and so forth. What I was unaware of was the degree of speaking with the media. But...it makes sense. Whether a research study claims they have found the miracle food of youth or whether "People" magazine has just reported on Jessica Simpson's Lemonade Diet, people are interested in nutrition-related topics.
It is the job of the media relations staff to use Saint Louis University faculty to provide the most up-to-date and accurate information to inform our public. It is not only part of our job, but it is the Dietitian's professional responsibility as well. However, when I first started, I was unaware that when they called the camera man was on his way over, whether you had decided to comb your hair and apply make-up or not that day. At first, I said "no" to these interviews quite frequently. I wanted time to look my best and time to be prepared to provide every correct detail of information as possible.
Today, I did my 6th or 7th live interview on Fox 2 News. And yes, as mentioned previously in another blog, I was the food police...educating people on how to improve the nutritional quality of their holiday meal (the one meal they really want to splurge on).
I have learned a lot about working with media since I started this job at SLU.
1) They want black and white anwers, aka "Foods we should eat and foods we should never eat" is a much catchier title than "All foods in moderation..."
2) They work on deadlines, telling them, "let me read the 20 literature articles out on the issue, and I will get back to you next week" won't cut it.
3) They like lists. "Top 5 ways to lose weight fast" is much more of an attractive topic than "Weight loss is a marathon, not a sprint"
4) They don't do your make-up. I always thought that anyone who went on TV would be touched up by the make-up crew. Nope, if I have a huge hair colic sticking straight up on my head, I get no love or help. You are on your own!
I have come along way since my first grocery store interview. I definitely still get very nervous, but I have learned to embrace my media opportunities, and provide the service to those interested by providing quick, yet informed, and hopefully somewhat entertaining (because that's what the media wants) information!

item.title: Foods & the Flu
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
It seems like everyone I know is sick or has been sick in the last month. I can't remember the last time the bug seemed to be so rampant! Even the softest cloth these days is still painful on my rudolph nose.
Unfortunatley, I rarely lose my appetite when I am sick. I just tend to crave the comfort foods of my childhood when mom would bring on our wicker tray table the ususal suspects: Ginger ale, saltine crackers, and Campbell's Chicken Noodle soup.
Now that I am not near my family, being sick isn't quite as easy. Its tough to be sick and alone! Of course we still seek pity and call home to complain. I get the same advice everytime, "load up on your vitamin C". As many times as I have told her that her advice of vitamin C to cure the common cold remains unproven, she holds strong to her mom advice.
I did read an interesting (non-peer reviewed journal) article about other foods that might be of some benefit during times of sniffles and coughs. If you like to eat soup when you are sick, add some mushrooms and barley! Mushrooms such as cremini, portobello or white button and grains such as barley contain a carbohydrate componenet called beta-glucan that has shown to support the immune system. Another food weapon, garlic, has been shown to ward off bacteria. Garlic contains allicin, which assists in killing bacteria.
Even though you might not feel up to making breakfast when you are sick. Find somebody to bring you breakfast in bed. By skipping breakfast, you miss out on the fuel you need to recover from an overnight fast, and compromise your ability to fight off the bugs.
Eating fruits and veggies that are deep in color also ensures you get an array of vitamins, minerals, and phytochemicals to ward off illness. If your sore throat doesn't feel like a salad of ruffage, make a smoothie with frozen berries, juice, and carrots. You will not even notice those carrots!
If you are sick, I wish you a speedy recovery, and if you aren't sick yet, eat healthy now, an apple (or mushrooms, garlic, and barley) really might keep the doctor away!

item.title: Holiday "Cheer"
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
Not only do we celebrate the holiday's with food, some of us also partake in celebratory beverages. The percentage of alcohol sold soars over from Thanksgiving to New Years. There are many reasons why one might drink more over the holidays such as celebrating, dealing with stress, increased availability, coping with family, etc.
Drinking in moderation has defintely been assoicated with positive health benefits, but the truth to health lies in the word "moderation." One drink per day for women and two for men didn't arbitraerly get pulled out the air. It is based on an amount that your liver can comfortably meatbolize, and more than this increases your risk for diseases like heart disease and cancer. Women get less than men, because 1) they have less of an enzyme that metabolizes alcohol and 2) are usually smaller in size.
So what is one drink? 5 oz of wine (red, white or champagne), 12 oz beer (light or regular) and 1 1/2 oz of hard liquor.
Well, like some of you, I enjoy many holiday concoctions, so I will provide you a little guidance on the popular choices of the season to keep you enjoying the festivities while being in the know about your favorite drinks.
Let's start with a beer comparision. Beer calories will depend on the percent alcohol as well as the carbohydrate content. Light beers usually are 4-5% alcohol and will cost you ~100-120 calories. The Sierra Nevada "Celebration" beer on the other hand contain 6.8% alcohol and contain 215 calories.
Wine whether red or white in a 5 oz portion are ~100 calories. The sweeter the wine, the more calories. My mom makes an amazing mulled wine cider, which contains red wine, apple cider, and spices, unfortunately this tasty drink has 100 additional calories than actual wine.
Liquor: The oz and a half of liquor contain ~100 calories, but it is the mixers that bump up the calories. If this is a concern, try diet tonic, club soda, or diet sodas to add to the liquor.
DDD's: Decandent Desserts in Disguise: Eggnog with rum: 8 oz= 375 calories
Hot buttered rum: 8 oz = 300
Hot chocolate with peppermint schnapps and whipped cream = 500 calories YIKES!

item.title: Lenten Health
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: Its' Friday.  Have you eaten meat yet? As a Catholic, I will be observing "meatless" Friday's until Easter. I did have a morningstar soy sausage link this morning, which still felt wrong. A Lenten Health benefit is the possibility that you may be eating more fish! The fish counter can be quite overwhelming though. Fresh or frozen? Am I purchasing a sustainable choice? What is the healthiest? Which has too much mercury? Even to dietitians the process is daunting.  Let's start with fresh versus frozen & terminology. Due to our midwest location, sometimes buying fresh really isn't "fresh."  Fresh fish can caught up to two weeks ago, and stored on the boats until it reaches your grocery store ice. As the fish expert at the grocery store about the freshest options, and look for a dense flesh without any gaps between the fish layers and bright clear eyes. In addition, if the fish is wrapped in plastic, the fish should contain little to no liquid. If buying frozen, look for the words: "frozen at sea." This preservation method results in a very freshlike form.

item.title: I survived the Swine Flu
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
So I wasn't diagnosed, and I feel like putting the word "swine flu" in my email might set off a huge stream of alerts across the university, and my computer might shut down as I write this blog.
Symptoms included: cough, runny nose, low grade fever for 4 days, aches, and chills. I missed 3 days of schools and felt like a old hermit trapped in my house.
Could I have warded off this pig flu sooner than I did if I had made the perfect dietary decisions? Should I have "starved the fever and fed the cold?" Your body needs the right nutrients to fight off those bugs, so which one are they?

item.title: 7 Reasons to Make Your Own Salad Dressing
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
Don't you love recipes that come out of the heads of kids? It's a common young school-aged project, to ask kids to provide the ingredients for their favorite recipes and create a "cookbook" (even if none of the entries would actually result in anything edible.) When I was asked to to assist with this task as a 5 year-old. I told my teacher that my favorite recipe was my mom's wilted spinach salad (was I born to be a dietitian or what?). After providing my teacher with salad components, the last ingredient I mentioned was that you HAD to use Paul Newman's salad dressing, because part of the proceeds would be given to charity. I still don't know how I knew that tidbit.
Sorry Paul, today I am urging our readers to make their own salad dressing and here is why.
1) Salad dressing can be expensive, especially if you buy it, don't like it and throw it away.
2) Making your own salad dressing is a great way to use up random ingredients in your refrigerator.
3) You've got control over the calories/contents.
4) You're being good to the planet by decreasing your plastic bottle consumption.
5) You avoid eating ingredients you can't pronounce.
6) You will impress guests. For some reason, making your own salad dressings gets you big props.
7) Homemade dressing tastes better and is fresh.
So if one of these reasons is enough to get your salad juices flowing, where to start? First of all you will need a vessel for the dressing. I have a plastic salad bottle carafe that has guiding ingredient lines for quick reference, but a washed wine bottle or easy to pour from container works just as well.
Now for the ingredients: For most dressings, you need at least 3 components: 1) oil 2) acid 3) flavorings.
Oil: Most of the time I use olive oil for it's healthy fats, but I also have used walnut or sesame oil depending on the type of flavor profile I am looking for. Canola oil is also a healthy oil, and does not carry much flavor.
Acid: Examples of acids include citrus, vinegars, or wine. I tend to use balsamic vinegar and orange juice.
Flavorings: Depending on your salad, flavorings might include herbs like basil, shallots, onions, mustards, cheese, salt/pepper, horseradish, wasabi, soy sauce, ginger. This list could never end.
Now for two of my favorite salad dressing recipes:

item.title: Holiday Heros
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: What do cranberries, pomegranate, red wine, nuts, and cinnamon all have on common? They are all holiday superfoods, and I would gladly include them in my diet every day diet if possible. In fact I think we should! Here is why and some simple creative ways to answer the question, how? Fresh Cranberries: These ruby red fruits top the antioxidant chart, and are rich in Vitamin C and tannins which have anti-bacterial properties are responsible for protection against urinary tract infection and gingivitis. However, don't let your berries get canned...the enormous amt of sugar and high fructose corn syrup overpower their naturally delcious flavors. Cranberry Chutney In a medium sized saucepan, simmer 4 cups of chopped fresh cranberries, 1 cup balsamic vinegar, a cup of red wine (something worthy of drinking) , the juice of one orange, one minced garlic clove, a tablespoon of honey, and a rosemary sprig. Once the sauce thickens and is reduced to about half, strain off the juices and use as a topping for pork or red meat or as colorful condiment with a nut and cheese plate. Nuts The holidays aren't

item.title: It's Getting "Chill"ier in Saint Louis
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: St. Louis is quickly catching on... Somewhere back in one of my old blogs, I "complained" about St. Louis not being a "yogurt-friendly" town.  Saint Louis does have some spectacular ice cream parlors like Serendipity in Webster Groves and delicious Gelato from Gelato de Riso in Des Peres.  However, I have a sweet tooth that needs feeding more than the average ice cream lover, and if I indulged in the "real" thing as much as I would like, I would have to ride my bike back and forth from SLU way more than I am currently doing. Luckily, a year or so ago, St. Louis was blessed with Fro Yo, a self-serve frozen yogurt store located in the Delmar Loop.  Last week, I discovered another yogurt store nugget called "Chill" located in Clayton. Chill was started by a family here in St. Louis who had realized their families own love of frozen yogurt while traveling out West on vacations. Can't make up your mind on which frozen yogurt stand to check out? Wait till you are faced with all the topping choices...Here are some bite size facts to help you make a decision. Location: Fro Yo: 1) 6329 Delmar Blvd 2) 10909 Olive Blvd - Creve Coeur 3 & 4) Locations in California - see their website @ www.froyoyogurt.com if you are traveling and need your fix Chill: 1) 7610 Wydown - Clayton Taste Although I have not (YET) tasted all flavors from either store.  Chills' yogurts seem to be more on the "tart" true yogurt tasting side than a creamer ice cream taste and mouth feel.  I would describe Chill's yogurt as  refreshing and Fro Yo's version as indulgent. Both stores have flavors which contain the word "tart" which do taste more like Dannon or Yoplait yogurts are just exactly that, more tart than they are sweet. Choices Both Chill and Fro Yo have 10 or self serving

item.title: All Things Pumpkin
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: Orange is my favorite color. Though many people would argue that the Tennessee Vols orange color is obnoxious and that teams like the Florida Gators or Texas Longhorns sport much more becoming orange shades, I as a TN volunteer would have to disagree. [caption id="attachment_470" align="alignleft" width="300" caption="Beautiful UT Orange"] [/caption] Not only am I wearing more orange these days, I am eating a lot of "orange" in the form of pumpkins.  Who can resist the pumpkin lattes or  pumpkin flavored ice cream?  Ted Drewes Pumpkin Concrete is amazing, but as a dietitian, my inspiration will support some healthier ideas. The pumpkin is quite the superfood squash.  Its bright orange color contains tons of beta carotene that protects our body from aging and degenerative diseases. One cup of cooked pumpkin has just 50 calories, 3 grams of fiber, and a wide array of vitamins and minerals. Pumpkins just like any other squash can be easily baked and turned into a delicious soup or bread.  However, sometimes, I want pumpkin in flash, and I turn to the good old canned pumpkin. Here are 3 of my favorite pumpkin in a flash meal ideas... 1) Pumpkin oatmeal:  Mix 1/2 cup old fashioned oats, 1/4 cup canned pumpkin, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 Tbsp honey, and 1 Tbsp sliced nuts. Heat in microwave...and your morning breakfast will smell like a little piece of heaven. 2) Pumpkin pudding: Mix 1 cup vanilla flavored yogurt, 1/4 cup canned pumpkin, and 2-3 Tbsp light cool-whip.  A perfectly healthy and delicious dessert. 3) Pumpkin pancakes:  Mix in 1/4 -1/2 cup canned pumpkin into your pancake batter, with 1 Tbsp crunchy peanut butter, 1 tsp vanilla, 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon allspice. Sometimes, just adding one ingredient to your recipe can significantly improve its nutritional grade. Even the local squirrels recognize the superfood power of the pumpkin...they started carving it before we got the chance! [caption id="attachment_472" align="alignleft" width="225" caption="Dang Squirrels!"] [/caption]

item.content:encoded: Jack is Here!

item.title: Feeding a New Mouth
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: Up until 6 months of age, feeding Jack was quite easy...all I had to worry about was the quantity of the milk he was drinking.  While some parents are so excited to feed their infant solids, I was a nervous!  As a dietitian, it might be expected that I should know how to nourish my child, but infant nutrition was something I hadn't reviewed since school many years ago. I wanted to do this right. I wanted to create a perfectly positive eating environment. I wanted to be perfectly OK if he shunned his veggies.  I wanted to introduce each food in a very strategic manner. Well, just like anything else in raising Jack, things have gone as planned.  There are some things I have not compromised, like feeding him mostly organic foods, letting him be the guide on "how much" he eats, and reminding myself to enjoy all messes and let them be opportunities for just plain fun and learning. Things that haven't gone as planned? Well, Jack's first real food that he mowed down with enjoyment was not the sweet potatoes or healthy vegetable I envisioned, but were Mexican beans from the restaurant, Pueblo Solis. Beans, I was ok with, but who knows how much lard and salt are added to make those beans so finger licking good? O well, it was a great moment for both Pj and me to see natural enjoyment in food. [caption id="attachment_657" align="alignleft" width="224" caption="Jack embraces his first food, Mexican Beans! "] [/caption] Other fun moments of learning was that using prepared baby food made more sense when we were still learning how to simply "eat" and use a spoon. Spending a couple hours in the kitchen making food only be played with and get as far as his lips didn't make much sense. Thank goodness for Tyler Florence's Sweet Potato and White Beans concoction...Jack opens his mouth gleefully after a first taste of chef's prepared babyfood. Now that eating has become more natural to Jack, making his food is much more rewarding. I will spend a couple hours on Sunday roasting veggies and fruits, or steaming and pureeing them in my wonder machine, the "Baby Cook." [caption id="attachment_658" align="alignleft" width="224" caption="Roasted vegetables and fruits ready for the Baby Cook! "] [/caption]

item.title: Sloppy Joe Reformed? Check out the changes to the school lunch program
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
For the first time since the 1990's, the school lunch program is getting a healthy makeover. Here are the specifics on what to expect if you are sending your child off to eat to school this year.
PORTIONS: Calorie min and MAXes. Schools have always had to meet a minimum calorie level for meals, but now there is an upper limit: K-5 550-650 calories 6-8 600-700 calories 9-12 750-850 calories
GRAINS: This year at least 1/2 of the grains offered must be whole-grain rich. Next year, 100% of those grains must be whole-grain rich.
VEGETABLES &; FRUITS: The amount offered will double, and schools must offer a variety of dark green, red/orange, beans, and starches.
MILK: Milk must be skim or 1%. Flavored milks must be skim. In the past, all levels of fat were acceptable.
SODIUM:

item.title: My Favorite Type of Pi...
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: Lately, whenever a friend suggests we grab I bite to eat, I struggle between two choices, Katie's Pizzeria Cafe and Pi .  Both of these fairly new restaurants  offer a unique twist to the traditional hand tossed pizza. I love Katie's pizza for the use of fresh ingredients and in-season produce, like the squash blossom pizza and I crave the San Francisco, deep-dish cornmeal crust pizza from Pi. Pi's pizzas have the best red, roasted tomato topping I have ever tasted. I have banned taking leftovers home from either of these places because I find myself opening up the pizza box at odd, non-meal times of the day.

item.title: A Favorite Wedding Gift
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
Last Sunday, PJ and I opened some remaining gifts from our wedding. PJ was taking a break watching football, but after hearing me squeal with excitement about the next gift I had opened, ran into the kitchen to see what I had unwrapped. My first pressure cooker! PJ couldn't figure out what all the enthusiasm was about and meanered back into the TV room. The Kuhn Rikon pressure cooker is considered to be the Mercedes Benz of pressure cookers. Why is this such a great tool?
  • Healthier You can cook with less fat or oil using a pressure cooker and your dishes retain more nutrients than with traditional cooking methods.
  • Faster Dishes cook in 2/3 less time than with regular cooking methods.
  • Tastier Pressure cooking retains and intensifies flavors, melding them more quickly, while the pressure produced tenderizes tougher cuts of meat and softens beans, improving textures and flavors.
  • Eco-Friendly With pressure cookers you use 70% less energy than traditional cooking methods, saving precious resources and reducing your carbon footprint .

item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
I am originally from from Hendersonville, Tennessee. My bachelor's degree was in Nutrition and Dietetics from The University of Tennessee at Knoxville. Go Vols!

I moved to St. Louis in 2000 because I matched at Saint Louis University for my dietetic internship. At SLU, I completed my dietetic internship and Masters degree in Nutrition and Physical Performance.

As a Registered Dietitian, I have worked with children and parents in a weight management program, counseled athletes on ways to improve performance with the right nutrition prescription, educated individuals who have diabetes in an outpatient clinic, and currently teach and act as the Undergraduate Director in the Department of Nutrition and Dietetics. 

My students inspire me, and my job at SLU is a gift!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am interested in your program to launch a 2nd career. I have a BS and a BA from Purdue University (1976) and an MBA from Washington University (1985). Is it possible to take only the courses that are of interest to me or to get a certification with out completing the 4 year course? I am interested in the Nutrition and Dietetics with a Culinary emphasis. Please let me know if there are any options for me since I have already completed undergraduate and graduate work, just not in nutrition. Thank you, Julie Ferrie

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Lauren Antonucci, MS, RD, CSSD, CDE, CDN
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Jennifer, As a fellow Registered Dietitian and marathon runner, I can relate to much of what you said above and write about in your blog. I commend you for taking the time and energy to blog daily, and loved the "drinking nights have turned fro yo excursions" entry! ;) I saw your recent entry regarding ACSM fluid guidelines and the importance of maintaining fluid balance for optimal athletic performance, and wanted to add a few points. It is absolutely true that maintaining adequate hydration status should be the primary nutrition focus for athletes. No other nutritional intervention aids sports performance more. However, although drinking water during exercise is certainly better than not drinking at all ;), but is not considered adequate to keep athletes performing their best. Sports drinks, such as Gatorade Thirst Quencher provided a much needed 14 grams of carbohydrate and 110mg of sodium per 8oz. This scientifically studied blend serves to both help increase an athlete's drive to drink (due to both the flavor and sodium content), and provides much needed carbs for energy to fuel working muscles. There is, as I am sure you know, another great option for endurance athletes (such as both you and I during our marathon training), in Gatorade Endurance Formula. The higher sodium content in this blend (200mg/8oz) helps endurance athletes better keep up with their electrolyte losses during prolonged exercise, further decreasing our risk of dehydration. G2, is a great option, as I am sure you are aware, for athletes who need additional electrolytes (110mg of sodium & 30mg of potassium per 8oz serving), with only half the calories of regular sports drinks, (25 cals per 8oz serving), but is designed to be used as an "off the field hydrator", and not in place of G or Gatorade Endurance during activity. Finally, Propel, is an "enhanced water". As such, it is important for our clients an specifically athletes to know that it is also not designed to take the place of a sports drink, but to provide a low calorie (10cals/8oz) alternative to regular water in order to encourage adequate drinking and therefore hydration in the course of one's "normal day". Ok, that is certainly more than enough from me for one day. ;) I hope you enjoy your July 4th Holiday weekend and good luck with your marathon training! Cheers, Lauren Antonucci

item.title: My First Post
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded:
I have to say I am a little nervous about my new assignment as a "blogger"...at the age of almost 30, I straddle the fence as far as my skills go related to the internet communication venues such as facebook, etc. But, as your "health" or "nutrition" expert of the this new blogging project, I promise to keep my readers updated on a couple of things...

1) "hot topics" in the field of nutrition and health

2) the fabulous menu of our sustainable food systems cafeteria, Fresh Gatherings , located on the Doisy College of Health Sciences Campus

3) my favorite new restaurants in St. Louis

There will probably be much more, and I know I will continue to be inspired by unique and grandiose projects of our current and future SLU students!

item.title: stir it up!
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: This week, I attended a class our nutrition students are required to take called "Nutrition Organic Tutorial."  The tutorial didn't start until 7 p.m., so I decided to check out the new stir-fry restaurant on campus called Santo Bento, santobento.com . I looked over the menu, and decided to order the salmon stir-fry. The gentleman who took my order informed me all foods were cooked in pure canola oil and contained no trans-fats. Although, many of our nutrition students would love to avoid chemistry...the students I would soon visit would be able to scientifically explain why canola oil should be included in our diets and why trans fats should be avoided. All of Santo Bento's menu items contained an array of vegetables such as broccoli, cabbage, carrots, and peas and allowed you to choose from an assortment of proteins including lean choices such as shrimp, salmon, chicken, and tofu. The next tough choice was whether to put your veggies and protein on a salad, on Jasmine or brown rice, or on top of a bed of noodles.  The menu prices were quite reasonable and ranged from $5.99 to $6.99. I left feeling comfortably full and ready to engage in a discussion about the structure of trans fats!

item.title: Buying Local...on Campus!
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: Fresh fruits and vegetables, homemade breads and baked goods...YUM! All of these foods will be sold at SLU's first farmer's market this week! Fresh Gatherings Cafe , our Nutrition and Dietetics run cafeteria, along with Chartwell's and the SLU School of Public Health will be hosting SLU's first farmer's market. The event will take place on Wednesday, September 19th, from 10am-2pm in the quad in front of Terra Ve. Produce offered by Fresh Gatherings Cafe will be locally produced by Missouri and Illinois farmers. So why buy locally? Buying locally... 1) Saves food miles: for example, a typical carrot bought from the grocery store travels an average of 1,838 miles to reach your dining table. Decreasing food miles helps protect our environment by using less fuel and packaging. 2) Provides you with foods which contain more nutrients. Fresh food from local farms don't spend days in trucks and on store shelves losing nutrients. They taste better too! 3) Buying local foods supports the small farmer and supports our local communities. If you are interested in finding about more ways to buy locally visit " food routes " where you can find out about restaurants, grocery stores, and farmer's markets which sell local foods in Missouri.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Farmer's Market, Why didn't we think of this earlier. Man I could use a good peach!

You bring up a good point! Some fruits and vegetables are only available at certain times of the year. To see what typically grows in Missouri, see "local harvest".
http://agebb.missouri.edu/fmktdir/harvest.gif

item.title: Diet Face-Off
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: Yesterday in my class called "Hot Topics in Nutrition", we examined a study which looked at 4 different popular diets.  The point of the study was to identify which diet worked best after 6 months in ~1,000 women. The 4 diet contenders were: Weight-Watchers on-line: (popular program for decades focusing on portion control, points assigned to foods for fat and fiber content) Dr. Atkins' New Revolution: (carbohydrate controlled diet) Eat More, Weigh Less: (low-fat diet program) The Way to Eat: (Mediterranean-style eating plan) AND THE WINNER IS? Results showed that Weight Watchers On-Line won the contest with the highest mean weight loss of ~11 pounds in 6 months. However,  this article brought up some other important issues... Dieting is hard! No matter what diet the people in this study followed, most people could not stick to the diet for 6 months. For example, within 3 months, 71% of the participants had dropped out. Every diet worked for someone. At least one person in each diet plan lost 30 or more pounds. Therefore, success was attributed to the fact that they could stick to the diet, not necessarily a reflection of the "type" of diet they followed. It had to become "automatic." Participants who succeeded in weight loss had committed to the realization that their changed eating behaviors were changes for life. The National Weight Control Registry is a registry which tracks successful dieters. They define weight-loss "success" as one who loses at least 30 pounds or more and is able to keep it off for greater than 1 year. Common characteristics of these dieters: 1) Used both diet and exercise to lose weight 2) Ate breakfast everyday 3) Consumed a low-fat, high carbohydrate diet 4) Weighed themselves frequently 5) Engaged in 60-90 minutes of moderate physical activity daily. Lesson of the day? There is no quick fix to health, but taking gradual steps to healthier eating and being more active will result in lost weight and more importantly...stays off.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Even though it's not a "hardcore" prescription type of diet pill, are diet pills like hydroxycut and Phentramin-d (http://www.buy-phentramin.com is where i found it) safe for me to use? I'm already doing the 5 steps and I know there's no quick fix but it's been a month and I only lost 4lbs and maybe that's just water weight... Can you help, Jenny? Thanks!!! ~Amy~
Great, informative blog post. It's helpful to hear how much physical activity is really necessary each day to maintain weight loss.
Found your blog from google.com This is information that is useful in any time period.Thanks for taking the time to share.

I have not tried the Weight Watchers diet yet, but I have been looking into it. What I do like about this study you mention is that it followed dieter for a period of 6 months. Too many diets are focusing on shorter term results for weight loss. What I have found in my quick diet research so far, is that it is easier to lose weight at the beginning of a diet due to your metabolism. Your metabolism actually slows down as you lose weight (in most cases), which makes it more difficult to lose further weight.

item.title: Tomato Tomata
item.dc:creator: jennifer
item.content:encoded: A picture of tomatoes from Fresh Gatherings Cafe at the last Farmer's Market on North Campus reminds us of the wonderful flavor of a good homegrown summer tomato. Unfortunately, homegrown tomatoes are leaving us quickly for the fall...But! You will be happy to know of the benefits of eating processed tomatoes, such as tomato sauce and ketchup! Scientists have discovered that packaged, heat processed tomato products, such as spaghetti sauce, can deliver over 6 times more lycopene than the equivalent amount of fresh tomatoes. This is because the heat used during processing breaks down the tomato cell walls, allowing the lycopene to be better absorbed in your digestive track. It's important to note that lycopene is fat soluble. This means lycopene is better absorbed when it is eaten with fat. So if you are a fan of olive oil, cheese, or meat (aka pizza), now you have another excuse to eat another slice!
